ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: - Literary Analysis in various styles including drama, prose, and lyric
How to read quickly, right lots of papers, and think thoughtfully about large amounts of content.
A better understanding of the later centures of the Western literary canon! Also, better close reading and analysis skills, as well as essay writing.

I greatly developed my skill of literary analysis through close reading, done in class and for essays. I also expanded my writing skills, incorporating themes we talked about in class, and learning how to build strong arguments. Additionally, I gained a good introduction to many seminal works in the later Western Canon.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof Ellermann did a wonderful job of managing the packed DS syllabus and gave very helpful introductions with each text. He came in with a plan and specific passages for us to read from without dominating the conversation too much. Most classes go by slowly, but this one always would fly by :)

DS is awesome! learn tons and great people. lovely community develops around it! downsides are that you don't relaly get an in depth understanding of many of the texts, because you go so quickly. also there is disparity in grading policy between sections, and generally a lack of feedback based on how the course is structured.

Strengths: exposure to many texts in a relatively short amount of time that I would not otherwise be able to interact with on a regular basis.
Weaknesses: many texts in a relatively short amount of time; I wish we had more time for each of the texts to really dig into the works. A week (or sometimes a couple days) per work did not do them justice enough, in my opinion!

I greatly enjoyed this course. I liked the small seminar format, which give everyone ample opportunities to speak. I also enjoyed having introductions to the works we read. Discussions were engaging and well structured, and the portions we read in class were interesting and relevant to themes we were talking about.
A strength was that every student was really encouraged to share often and I felt as though our thoughts were appreciated. A weakness was that often the energy of the class was low.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you'd like to do DS!

I loved DS! There's no other way that I would've been able to read all of these great books in my life if not at this absurd and rapid pace. Of the three, lit was my least favorite, but that's really just because I'm more inclined towards H&P and philosophy. All around, good times, good community, interesting readings in DS.
Yes, but only for students that are really passionate about reading and/or talking in depth about the works. This applies to the DS curriculum in general!
I would greatly recommend this course. Discussions were always interesting and insightful, and Professor Ellerman is great at structuring discussions.
Absolutely!! The challenge and rigor of this course is well-worth any serious humanities students time.
Yes, DS Lit is a great way to discover what you like to read, to learn what's out there, and to discover strategies for interpretation.
